description: From a variant of flappy, from flap (“to hang loose”). Compare English dialectal flapsy (“flabby”), Middle Dutch flabbe (“a slap in the face; a fan-blade; a hair ribbon; a wagging tongue”), Middle Low German flabbe (“a gaping mouth; a chatterbox”), Danish flab (“the jaw; cheeks; a malapert”), Swedish flabb, fläff (“the hanging underlip of an animal; guffaw; driveller”), German Flabbe (“a gob; muzzle”).

entries.meaning: Yielding to the touch, and easily moved or shaken; hanging loose by its own weight; lacking firmness; flaccid.
(of wine) Having a slight lack of acidity; having mild sweetness.
(mathematics) Which forms a surjection from the domain to every open subset of the codomain.
examples: a flabby sheaf on a paracompact space
